M’s political Agent, Bahrain. . ^ Memorandum:- The Superintendent of the Public tforks Dep’t, Agha Mohamed Jafar who has held this post for about seven years proceeded on five months’ leave to India on 31st May 1944. He was granted an extension of three weeks and was paid his return air passage in advance. He has not returned. During this long period I have received several letters and telegrams from him, some of th^m in answer to my enquiries as to the cause of his delay in return ing to Bahrain. The reasons given were on the whole unsatisfactory and his final letter,, received by n%. ^ a few days ago, implies that he does not propose to return unless he is granted an increment -of fo. 100/- per month. He is now on the scale of Rs. 500/- per month, basic pay, and together with allowances he earns Rs. 625/- per month. In June last year Mohamed Jafar received the honour of Khan Sahib in the Birthday Honours. Mohamed Jafar is an old man and, I believe, in very comfortable circumstances. During his time in Bahrain he did good work. If when he went on leave he had told me that he wished to retire his resignation would have been accepted and we should have taken steps to fill his place. I consider however that he has behaved badly by neither returning to work in Bahrain or resigning his post. Under the circumstances I now^ feel compelled to infoim him that his services are terminated owing to his continued absence without leave. He has R5.3,40l/- in his Provident Fund representing his own and the Government’s contributions. Owing to^ the way in which he has behaved I propose to pay to him only his own contribution to this fund, deducting from it the cost of his passage back to Bahrain which was paid in advance, and the rent of his house which I understand has not been paid since he left. In view of the fact that he was made a Khan Sahib last year, on the recommendation of the Political Agent, and that he draws a pension from the Government of India I should be grateful for your views on the case before I take any action. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 30; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-10; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence. Pagination: a set of circled pagination numbers has been crossed out, to prevent confusion with the main foliation sequence.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence regarding Agha Mohamed Jafar, the Superintendent of the Public Works Department (PWD) in Bahrain.In May 1944, Jafar returned home to India on leave and in May 1945, after repeatedly delaying his return, wrote to Bahrain implying he would not return to his position unless he was given a pay rise.The correspondence discusses what should be done about Jafar's unsanctioned departure and the search for a replacement for him as Superintendent of the Public Works Department. Much of this correspondence is between Charles Belgrave, Adviser to the Government of Bahrain and the Political Agency in Bahrain.
